title: If a^2+b^2=0, what are the possible values of a and b? - Quora

response.answer_text: If a and b are real number. Then, a^2 >= 0 —— (1) And, b >= 0 —— (2) That is, both the values of a^2 and b^2 are greater than or equal to 0. That means, neither a^2 can be negative nor b^2 can be negative. Now, adding (1) and (2), a^2 + b^2 >= 0 Now for this inquation to hold true, both a^2 = 0 and b^2 = 0 So, a = 0 b = 0

The only possible value of A & B is 0. If we take any number except 0 it will not equal to 0. If you take any negative value, it's square will become positive. To make A²+B²=0, you need one negative value and the same value in positive. And square of negative value will become positive. So, if we take A=B=0 Then, any power of 0 will become 0. So… A²+B =0²+0² =0+0 =0 LHS=RHS That's why A=B=0. @Mathematics
